name: RNASkim
tagline: RNA-Skim: a rapid method for RNA-Seq quantification at transcript level
body:
RNASkim ======= RNA-Skim: a rapid method for RNA-Seq quantification at transcript level ## Clustering the transcripts based on their sequence similarities. TODO(zzj) ## Building the index for a given transcript clustering result This command downloads a clustering result of the mouse transcriptome. 
wget http://www.csbio.unc.edu/rs/clustered_gene.fa
The clustered_gene.fa file uses fasta format, but it may contain more than one transcript per two lines, for example: 
>gid|tid1|tid2
ATCTATTA|TACTAATC
This presents a transcript cluster named gid which contains two transcripts tid1 and tid2. And the sequence of tid1 is ATCTATTA and the sequence of tid2 is TACTAATC. "|" is the delimiter for both the sequence ids and the sequences. And the first id of the sequence ids is the gene id. Now you can run the following command to find all sig-mer regions. 
./rs_index -transcript_fasta=clustered_gene.fa -index_file=clustered_gene.fa.pb -num_threads 4
A sig-mer region is a sequence that all k-mers from the region are sig-mers of the transcript cluster. (Check out the document for the GeneSignatures class at rnasigs.proto for more details). The clustered_gene.fa.pb contains the corresponding GeneSignatures class for every transcript cluster. The default sig-mer size is 40. 
./rs_index -transcript_fasta=clustered_gene.fa -index_file=clustered_gene.fa.pb -rs_length 50 -num_threads 4
You can check all arguments information by 
./rs_index --help
**The "--help" parameter also works for other executables.** The output list all parameters into different sections by their source files, and only the parameters defined in the RNA-Skim sources (the file names start with "rs_") are defined by RNA-Skim. Or you can run 
./rs_index --helpshort
./rs_select --helpshort
./rs_count --helpshort
./rs_estimate --helpshort
to filter out all unnecessary parameters. ## Selecting sig-mers from the sig-mer regions OK, now you have the clustered_gene.fa.pb file. Let's select sig-mers from all sig-mer regions: 
./rs_select -index_file=clustered_gene.fa.pb -selected_keys_file=clustered_gene.fa.sk
**If you use sig-mer size other than the default value, you should specify the length in the parameter list as well,** for example: 
./rs_select -index_file=clustered_gene.fa.pb -selected_keys_file=clustered_gene.fa.sk  -rs_length 50
Please be careful about this. This is annoying and should be [fixed](https://github.com/zzj/rnasigs/issues/14). You may see some warnings like this, 
E0309 21:20:25.820291 1990034192 rs_select.cc:130] ENSMUST00000114890 has 1 rna_signatures. Skipped.
For some transcripts, RNA-Skim cannot get enough number of sig-mers, so it does not quantify such transcripts because the results of those transcripts are not reliable. Most of such transcripts are either too short (less than 150 bps) or categorized as "predicted gene". The output file (clustered_gene.fa.sk) is a list of SelectedKey objects. For details, please checkout the comments for SelectedKey at rnasigs.proto. ## Counting the sig-mers for a given RNA-Seq dataset Now, we run rs_count to count all sig-mers stored in the clustered_gene.fa.sk file. 
GLOG_logtostderr=1  ../src/rs_count  -selected_keys_file=clustered_gene.fa.sk -count_file=clustered_gene.fa.cf -read_files1=../test/test.fastq_1 -read_files2=../test/test.fastq_2 -num_threads=1 -rs_length (INPUT_YOUR_SIG_MER_LENGTH_HERE)
This generates clustered_gene.fa.cf file, which is almost identical with the clustered_gene.fa.sk file, but the count fields in the SelectedKey object in the clustered_gene.fa.cf file is the real occurrences of their corresponding sig-mers. ## Quantifying the abundances of transcripts This command quantifies the transcriptome based on the counts of sig-mers in the clustered_gene.fa.cf file. 
../src/rs_estimate -count_file=clustered_gene.fa.cf > estimation
There are four columns in the estimation file: transcript id; the length of the transcript; estimated number of relative reads; RPKM value of the transcript.
